## 18. Create Custom Matchers for Domain Logic
```typescript
// Custom matchers make tests more readable and maintainable
export const todoMatchers = {
 async toBeCompletedTask(locator: Locator) {
 const checkbox = locator.locator('input[type="checkbox"]');
 const isChecked = await checkbox.isChecked();
 const titleElement = locator.locator('[data-testid="task-title"]');
 const hasStrikethrough = await titleElement.evaluate(el => 
 getComputedStyle(el).textDecoration.includes('line-through')
 );
 
 return {
 pass: isChecked && hasStrikethrough,
 message: () => `Expected task to be completed (checked and strikethrough)`
 };
 }
};

expect.extend(todoMatchers);

// Usage in tests - more readable than generic assertions
await expect(task).toBeCompletedTask();

// Instead of:
expect(await task.locator('input').isChecked()).toBe(true);
expect(await task.locator('[data-testid="task-title"]').evaluate(el => 
 getComputedStyle(el).textDecoration.includes('line-through')
)).toBe(true);
````

run: PNPM_FROZEN_LOCKFILE=true pnpm install"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"..."},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"```"}]}]},"mentioned_items":[{"label":"package.json","name":"/package.json","id":"/package.json","file":{"repoRoot":"","pathName":"package.json"},"type":"item"},{"label":"playwright.config.ts","name":"/playwright.config.ts","id":"/playwright.config.ts","recentFile":{"repoRoot":"","pathName":"playwright.config.ts"},"type":"item"}],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":1,"type":0,"content":"Based on your `package.json` and `playwright.config.ts`, here's a complete GitHub Actions pipeline for running e2e tests:

<augment_code_snippet path=".github/workflows/e2e-tests.yml" mode="EDIT">
```yaml
name: E2E Tests
on:
 push:
 branches: [ main, master ]
 pull_request:
 branches: [ main, master ]

jobs:
 e2e-tests:
 runs-on: ubuntu-latest
 container:
 image: mcr.microsoft.com/playwright:v1.52.0-jammy
 steps:
 - uses: actions/checkout@v4
 - uses: pnpm/action-setup@v4
 with:
 version: 8
 - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
 with:
 node-version: 20
 cache: 'pnpm'
 
 - name: Install dependencies
 run: pnpm install --frozen-lockfile
 
 - name: Build application
 run: pnpm run build
 
 - name: Run E2E tests
 run: pnpm run test:e2e
 env:
 CI: true
 
 - name: Upload test results
 uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
 if: always()
 with:
 name: playwright-report
 path: playwright-report/
 retention-days: 30
 
 - name: Upload JUnit results
 uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
 if: always()
 with:
 name: test-results
 path: test-results/
 retention-days: 30
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Key points:
- Uses Playwright v1.52.0 container (matching your installed version)
- Updated to latest action versions (v4)
- Uses `pnpm` with frozen lockfile for reproducible builds
- Builds the app before running tests (required for your `webServer` config)
- Uploads both HTML report and JUnit XML results
- Sets `CI=true` environment variable for proper CI behavior

The pipeline will run your `test:e2e` script which executes `playwright test` with your current configuration.

name: E2E Tests
on:
 push:
 branches: [ main, master ]
 pull_request:
 branches: [ main, master ]

jobs:
 e2e-tests:
 runs-on: ubuntu-latest
 container:
 image: mcr.microsoft.com/playwright:v1.52.0-jammy
 steps:
 - uses: actions/checkout@v4
 - uses: pnpm/action-setup@v4
 with:
 version: 8
 - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
 with:
 node-version: 20
 cache: 'pnpm'
 
 - name: Install dependencies
 run: pnpm install --frozen-lockfile
 
 - name: Build application
 run: pnpm run build
 
 - name: Run E2E tests
 run: pnpm run test:e2e
 env:
 CI: true
 
 - name: Upload test results
 uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
 if: always()
 with:
 name: playwright-report
 path: playwright-report/
 retention-days: 30
 
 - name: Upload JUnit results
 uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
 if: always()
 with:
 name: test-results
 path: test-results/
 retention-days: 30
````

Key points:
- Uses Playwright v1.52.0 container (matching your installed version)
- Updated to latest action versions (v4)
- Uses `pnpm` with frozen lockfile for reproducible builds
- Builds the app before running tests (required for your `webServer` config)
- Uploads both HTML report and JUnit XML results
- Sets `CI=true` environment variable for proper CI behavior

The pipeline will run your `test:e2e` script which executes `playwright test` with your current configuration.

Add the environment variable to the pipeline:

<augment_code_snippet path=".github/workflows/e2e-tests.yml" mode="EDIT">
```yaml
name: E2E Tests
on:
 push:
 branches: [ main, master ]
 pull_request:
 branches: [ main, master ]

jobs:
 e2e-tests:
 runs-on: ubuntu-latest
 container:
 image: mcr.microsoft.com/playwright:v1.52.0-jammy
 steps:
 - uses: actions/checkout@v4
 - uses: pnpm/action-setup@v4
 with:
 version: 8
 - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
 with:
 node-version: 20
 cache: 'pnpm'
 
 - name: Install dependencies
 run: pnpm install --frozen-lockfile
 
 - name: Build application
 run: pnpm run build
 env:
 DATABASE_URL: file:local.db
 
 - name: Run E2E tests
 run: pnpm run test:e2e
 env:
 CI: true
 DATABASE_URL: file:local.db
 
 - name: Upload test results
 uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
 if: always()
 with:
 name: playwright-report
 path: playwright-report/
 retention-days: 30
 
 - name: Upload JUnit results
 uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
 if: always()
 with:
 name: test-results
 path: test-results/
 retention-days: 30
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Added `DATABASE_URL=file:local.db` to both the build and test steps since your SvelteKit app needs it during build-time analysis and runtime.

test.describe('TodoApp - Basic Functionality', () => {","rich_text_json_repr":{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"as playwright expert run please only for CI thoses tests"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"test.describe('TodoApp - Basic Functionality', () => {"}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":1,"type":0,"content":"To run only the "TodoApp - Basic Functionality" tests in CI, update your GitHub Actions pipeline:

<augment_code_snippet path=".github/workflows/e2e-tests.yml" mode="EDIT">
```yaml
 - name: Run E2E tests
 run: pnpm run test:e2e --grep "TodoApp - Basic Functionality"
 env:
 CI: true
 DATABASE_URL: file:local.db
```
</augment_code_snippet>

This uses Playwright's `--grep` flag to run only tests within the "TodoApp - Basic Functionality" describe block. The grep pattern matches the describe block title exactly.

Alternatively, you could add a new npm script in `package.json` for CI-specific tests:

<augment_code_snippet path="package.json" mode="EDIT">
```json
		"test:e2e:ci": "playwright test --grep 'TodoApp - Basic Functionality'",
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Then use it in the pipeline:

<augment_code_snippet path=".github/workflows/e2e-tests.yml" mode="EDIT">
```yaml
 - name: Run E2E tests
 run: pnpm run test:e2e:ci
 env:
 CI: true
 DATABASE_URL: file:local.db
```
</augment_code_snippet>

This uses Playwright's `--grep` flag to run only tests within the "TodoApp - Basic Functionality" describe block. The grep pattern matches the describe block title exactly.

Alternatively, you could add a new npm script in `package.json` for CI-specific tests:

````json path=package.json mode=EDIT

````

Then use it in the pipeline:

````yaml path=.github/workflows/e2e-tests.yml mode=EDIT

at the error and page snapshot, the issue is clear: the "should delete a task" test is failing because the Work Projects section is **collapsed** (showing "▶" arrow), so the task "Fix authentication bug" is not visible.

The key difference between the working and failing tests:

## Working Test: "should toggle task completion"
- Uses `todoPageWithTasks` fixture 
- **Explicitly expands projects** before interacting with tasks:

<augment_code_snippet path="e2e/todo-app.test.ts" mode="EXCERPT">
```typescript
test('should toggle task completion @regression', async ({ todoPageWithTasks }) => {
 // Force expand both projects first
 const workExpanded = await todoPageWithTasks.isProjectExpanded('work');
 
 if (!workExpanded) {
 await todoPageWithTasks.toggleProject('work');
 await todoPageWithTasks.page.waitForTimeout(1000);
 }
 // ... continues with project expansion logic
});
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Failing Test: "should delete a task"
- Uses `todoPageWithTasks` fixture
- **Assumes task is visible** without ensuring project is expanded:

<augment_code_snippet path="e2e/todo-app.test.ts" mode="EXCERPT">
```typescript
test('should delete a task', async ({ todoPageWithTasks }) => {
 const taskTitle = testTasks.work.highPriority.title;
 
 // Verify task exists first - FAILS HERE because project is collapsed
 const task = await todoPageWithTasks.getTaskByTitle(taskTitle);
 await expect(task).toBeVisible();
});
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Root Cause
The `todoPageWithTasks` fixture in `e2e/fixtures/todoFixtures.ts` creates tasks but doesn't guarantee projects remain expanded. The page snapshot shows Work Projects is collapsed ("▶" instead of "▼").

## Solution
Add project expansion to the delete test:

<augment_code_snippet path="e2e/todo-app.test.ts" mode="EDIT">
```typescript
test('should delete a task', async ({ todoPageWithTasks }) => {
 const taskTitle = testTasks.work.highPriority.title;
 
 // Ensure work project is expanded before looking for task
 const workExpanded = await todoPageWithTasks.isProjectExpanded('work');
 if (!workExpanded) {
 await todoPageWithTasks.toggleProject('work');
 await todoPageWithTasks.page.waitForTimeout(500);
 }
 
 // Verify task exists first
 const task = await todoPageWithTasks.getTaskByTitle(taskTitle);
 await expect(task).toBeVisible();
 
 // Delete via context menu
 await todoPageWithTasks.deleteTaskFromMenu(taskTitle);
 
 // Verify task is removed
 await expect(task).not.toBeVisible();
});
```
</augment_code_snippet>

The `getTaskByTitle()` method in `TodoPage.ts` calls `ensureProjectExpanded()`, but this might not be working reliably. The explicit expansion in the toggle test is more robust.

The key difference between the working and failing tests:

## Working Test: "should toggle task completion"
- Uses `todoPageWithTasks` fixture 
- **Explicitly expands projects** before interacting with tasks:

````typescript path=e2e/todo-app.test.ts mode=EXCERPT
test('should toggle task completion @regression', async ({ todoPageWithTasks }) => {
 // Force expand both projects first
 const workExpanded = await todoPageWithTasks.isProjectExpanded('work');
 
 if (!workExpanded) {
 await todoPageWithTasks.toggleProject('work');
 await todoPageWithTasks.page.waitForTimeout(1000);
 }
 // ... continues with project expansion logic
});
````

## Failing Test: "should delete a task"
- Uses `todoPageWithTasks` fixture
- **Assumes task is visible** without ensuring project is expanded:

````typescript path=e2e/todo-app.test.ts mode=EXCERPT
test('should delete a task', async ({ todoPageWithTasks }) => {
 const taskTitle = testTasks.work.highPriority.title;
 
 // Verify task exists first - FAILS HERE because project is collapsed
 const task = await todoPageWithTasks.getTaskByTitle(taskTitle);
 await expect(task).toBeVisible();
});
````

## Root Cause
The `todoPageWithTasks` fixture in `e2e/fixtures/todoFixtures.ts` creates tasks but doesn't guarantee projects remain expanded. The page snapshot shows Work Projects is collapsed ("▶" instead of "▼").

## Solution
Add project expansion to the delete test:

````typescript path=e2e/todo-app.test.ts mode=EDIT
test('should delete a task', async ({ todoPageWithTasks }) => {
 const taskTitle = testTasks.work.highPriority.title;
 
 // Ensure work project is expanded before looking for task
 const workExpanded = await todoPageWithTasks.isProjectExpanded('work');
 if (!workExpanded) {
 await todoPageWithTasks.toggleProject('work');
 await todoPageWithTasks.page.waitForTimeout(500);
 }
 
 // Verify task exists first
 const task = await todoPageWithTasks.getTaskByTitle(taskTitle);
 await expect(task).toBeVisible();
 
 // Delete via context menu
 await todoPageWithTasks.deleteTaskFromMenu(taskTitle);
 
 // Verify task is removed
 await expect(task).not.toBeVisible();
});
````

The `getTaskByTitle()` method in `TodoPage.ts` calls `ensureProjectExpanded()`, but this might not be working reliably. The explicit expansion in the toggle test is more robust.

($HOME is /github/home which is owned by uid 1001.)"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":" - [pid=737] <process did exit: exitCode=1, signal=null>"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":" - [pid=737] starting temporary directories cleanup"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"```"}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":1,"type":0,"content":"Yes, this is a **very common** Firefox-specific issue in CI environments, especially GitHub Actions. The error has nothing to do with your test logic - it's a Firefox sandboxing problem.

## Root Cause
Firefox refuses to run as root when `$HOME` is owned by a different user (uid 1001 in your case). This happens because:
1. GitHub Actions runs in containers as root
2. The home directory is owned by the runner user (uid 1001)
3. Firefox's security model blocks this configuration

## Quick Fix
Set `HOME=/root` in your GitHub Actions workflow:

<augment_code_snippet path=".github/workflows/e2e-tests.yml" mode="EDIT">
```yaml
- name: Run E2E tests
 run: pnpm run test:e2e:ci
 env:
 CI: true
 HOME: /root
 DATABASE_URL: file:local.db
 ANTHROPIC_API_KEY: dummy_key
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Alternative Solutions

1. **Use Chromium only in CI** (most common approach):

<augment_code_snippet path="playwright.config.ts" mode="EDIT">
```typescript
projects: [
 {
 name: 'chromium',
 use: { ...devices['Desktop Chrome'] },
 },
 // Only run Firefox locally, not in CI
 ...(process.env.CI ? [] : [{
 name: 'firefox',
 use: { ...devices['Desktop Firefox'] },
 }]),
],
```
</augment_code_snippet>

2. **Disable Firefox sandbox** (less secure):

<augment_code_snippet path="playwright.config.ts" mode="EDIT">
```typescript
use: {
 launchOptions: {
 args: process.env.CI ? ['--no-sandbox'] : [],
 },
},
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Why This Happens
This is Firefox-specific because:
- **Chromium**: More permissive in containerized environments
- **Firefox**: Stricter security model, especially around user/root boundaries
- **WebKit**: Usually works fine in containers

The `HOME=/root` fix is the cleanest solution and widely used across the Playwright community.

```"}},{"id":1,"type":4,"ide_state_node":{"workspaceFolders":[{"repositoryRoot":"/Users/michal/PycharmProjects/clippio","folderRoot":"/Users/michal/PycharmProjects/clippio"}],"workspaceFoldersUnchanged":false}}],"timestamp":"2025-08-09T21:55:02.065Z","response_text":"Yes, this is a **very common** Firefox-specific issue in CI environments, especially GitHub Actions. The error has nothing to do with your test logic - it's a Firefox sandboxing problem.

## Root Cause
Firefox refuses to run as root when `$HOME` is owned by a different user (uid 1001 in your case). This happens because:
1. GitHub Actions runs in containers as root
2. The home directory is owned by the runner user (uid 1001)
3. Firefox's security model blocks this configuration

## Quick Fix
Set `HOME=/root` in your GitHub Actions workflow:

````yaml path=.github/workflows/e2e-tests.yml mode=EDIT
- name: Run E2E tests
 run: pnpm run test:e2e:ci
 env:
 CI: true
 HOME: /root
 DATABASE_URL: file:local.db
 ANTHROPIC_API_KEY: dummy_key
````

## Alternative Solutions

1. **Use Chromium only in CI** (most common approach):

````typescript path=playwright.config.ts mode=EDIT
projects: [
 {
 name: 'chromium',
 use: { ...devices['Desktop Chrome'] },
 },
 // Only run Firefox locally, not in CI
 ...(process.env.CI ? [] : [{
 name: 'firefox',
 use: { ...devices['Desktop Firefox'] },
 }]),
],
````

2. **Disable Firefox sandbox** (less secure):

````typescript path=playwright.config.ts mode=EDIT
use: {
 launchOptions: {
 args: process.env.CI ? ['--no-sandbox'] : [],
 },
},
````

## Why This Happens
This is Firefox-specific because:
- **Chromium**: More permissive in containerized environments
- **Firefox**: Stricter security model, especially around user/root boundaries
- **WebKit**: Usually works fine in containers

The `HOME=/root` fix is the cleanest solution and widely used across the Playwright community.

rounded-full"}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":1,"type":0,"content":"Yes, these are common accessibility warnings in Svelte. Here are the fixes:

## Fix 1: Interactive Element with Keyboard Events

The `<div>` has keyboard/mouse events but isn't interactive. Change it to a `<button>`:

<augment_code_snippet path="src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte" mode="EDIT">
```svelte
<button 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative w-full text-left"
 role="listitem"
 tabindex="0"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
>
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Fix 2: Remove `aria-pressed` from menuitem

`menuitem` role doesn't support `aria-pressed`. Use `aria-current` instead:

<augment_code_snippet path="src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte" mode="EDIT">
```svelte
<button
 onclick={() => setPriority(task.id, priority)}
 class="w-full flex items-center gap-2 px-3 py-2 text-sm text-gray-700 hover:bg-gray-100
 {task.priority === priority ? 'bg-blue-50 text-blue-700' : ''}"
 role="menuitem"
 aria-label="Set priority to {priority}"
 aria-current={task.priority === priority ? 'true' : undefined}
>
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Alternative: Use `<li>` for List Items

If you prefer semantic HTML, wrap in a proper list:

<augment_code_snippet path="src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte" mode="EDIT">
```svelte
<ul class="divide-y divide-gray-100" role="list">
 {#each tasks as task}
 <li>
 <button 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative w-full text-left"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
 >
 <!-- task content -->
 </button>
 </li>
 {/each}
</ul>
```
</augment_code_snippet>

The key principles:
- **Interactive elements** need proper roles (`button`, `link`, etc.)
- **ARIA attributes** must be supported by their roles
- **Keyboard events** should only be on focusable elements

190: <div class="w-2 h-2 rounded-full"}},{"id":1,"type":4,"ide_state_node":{"workspaceFolders":[{"repositoryRoot":"/Users/michal/PycharmProjects/clippio","folderRoot":"/Users/michal/PycharmProjects/clippio"}],"workspaceFoldersUnchanged":false}}],"timestamp":"2025-08-09T22:04:15.121Z","response_text":"Yes, these are common accessibility warnings in Svelte. Here are the fixes:

## Fix 1: Interactive Element with Keyboard Events

The `<div>` has keyboard/mouse events but isn't interactive. Change it to a `<button>`:

````svelte path=src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte mode=EDIT
<button 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative w-full text-left"
 role="listitem"
 tabindex="0"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
>
````

## Fix 2: Remove `aria-pressed` from menuitem

`menuitem` role doesn't support `aria-pressed`. Use `aria-current` instead:

````svelte path=src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte mode=EDIT
<button
 onclick={() => setPriority(task.id, priority)}
 class="w-full flex items-center gap-2 px-3 py-2 text-sm text-gray-700 hover:bg-gray-100
 {task.priority === priority ? 'bg-blue-50 text-blue-700' : ''}"
 role="menuitem"
 aria-label="Set priority to {priority}"
 aria-current={task.priority === priority ? 'true' : undefined}
>
````

## Alternative: Use `<li>` for List Items

If you prefer semantic HTML, wrap in a proper list:

````svelte path=src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte mode=EDIT
<ul class="divide-y divide-gray-100" role="list">
 {#each tasks as task}
 <li>
 <button 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative w-full text-left"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
 >
 <!-- task content -->
 </button>
 </li>
 {/each}
</ul>
````

The key principles:
- **Interactive elements** need proper roles (`button`, `link`, etc.)
- **ARIA attributes** must be supported by their roles
- **Keyboard events** should only be on focusable elements

The outer task row is a `<button>`, and the three-dot menu button is also a `<button>` inside it. HTML doesn't allow nested buttons.

## Solution: Use `<div>` for Task Row, `<button>` for Menu

<augment_code_snippet path="src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte" mode="EDIT">
```svelte
<div 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative"
 role="listitem"
 tabindex="0"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
>
 <input
 type="checkbox"
 checked={task.completed}
 onchange={() => onTaskToggle(projectId, task.id)}
 class="w-4 h-4 text-blue-600 rounded focus:ring-blue-500"
 aria-label="Mark task {task.completed ? 'incomplete' : 'complete'}"
 />
 
 <div class="flex-1 min-w-0">
 <div class="flex items-center gap-2">
 <span 
 data-testid="task-title"
 class="text-sm font-medium {task.completed ? 'line-through text-gray-500' : 'text-gray-900'}"
 >
 {task.title}
 </span>
 <span class="inline-flex items-center px-2 py-1 rounded-full text-xs font-medium
 {task.priority === 'high' ? 'bg-red-100 text-red-800' : 
 task.priority === 'medium' ? 'bg-yellow-100 text-yellow-800' : 
 'bg-gray-100 text-gray-800'}"
 aria-label="Priority: {task.priority}">
 {task.priority}
 </span>
 </div>
 </div>
 
 <button 
 onclick={(e) => toggleDropdown(task.id, e)}
 class="opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 p-1 rounded hover:bg-gray-200 transition-opacity"
 aria-label="Open task menu for {task.title}"
 aria-expanded={openDropdown === task.id}
 >
 <MoreVertical class="w-4 h-4 text-gray-500" />
 </button>
</div>
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Why This Works
- **`<div>`** with `tabindex="0"` makes it focusable and keyboard accessible
- **`role="listitem"`** maintains semantic meaning
- **`<button>`** for the menu is now properly nested inside a div, not another button
- **Event handlers** work the same way on the div

This is a common pattern in accessible UI components where you need both clickable areas and nested interactive elements.

The outer task row is a `<button>`, and the three-dot menu button is also a `<button>` inside it. HTML doesn't allow nested buttons.

## Solution: Use `<div>` for Task Row, `<button>` for Menu

````svelte path=src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte mode=EDIT
<div 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative"
 role="listitem"
 tabindex="0"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
>
 <input
 type="checkbox"
 checked={task.completed}
 onchange={() => onTaskToggle(projectId, task.id)}
 class="w-4 h-4 text-blue-600 rounded focus:ring-blue-500"
 aria-label="Mark task {task.completed ? 'incomplete' : 'complete'}"
 />
 
 <div class="flex-1 min-w-0">
 <div class="flex items-center gap-2">
 <span 
 data-testid="task-title"
 class="text-sm font-medium {task.completed ? 'line-through text-gray-500' : 'text-gray-900'}"
 >
 {task.title}
 </span>
 <span class="inline-flex items-center px-2 py-1 rounded-full text-xs font-medium
 {task.priority === 'high' ? 'bg-red-100 text-red-800' : 
 task.priority === 'medium' ? 'bg-yellow-100 text-yellow-800' : 
 'bg-gray-100 text-gray-800'}"
 aria-label="Priority: {task.priority}">
 {task.priority}
 </span>
 </div>
 </div>
 
 <button 
 onclick={(e) => toggleDropdown(task.id, e)}
 class="opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 p-1 rounded hover:bg-gray-200 transition-opacity"
 aria-label="Open task menu for {task.title}"
 aria-expanded={openDropdown === task.id}
 >
 <MoreVertical class="w-4 h-4 text-gray-500" />
 </button>
</div>
````

## Why This Works
- **`<div>`** with `tabindex="0"` makes it focusable and keyboard accessible
- **`role="listitem"`** maintains semantic meaning
- **`<button>`** for the menu is now properly nested inside a div, not another button
- **Event handlers** work the same way on the div

This is a common pattern in accessible UI components where you need both clickable areas and nested interactive elements.

issue is that `<li>` elements are semantic containers, not interactive elements. You have two clean solutions:

## Solution 1: Use `<div>` with `role="listitem"` (Recommended)

<augment_code_snippet path="src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte" mode="EDIT">
```svelte
<ul class="border-t border-gray-200 divide-y divide-gray-100" role="list">
 {#if tasks.length === 0}
 <li class="p-4 text-center text-gray-500 text-sm">
 No tasks yet. Add one above!
 </li>
 {:else}
 {#each tasks as task}
 <div 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative"
 role="listitem"
 tabindex="0"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
 >
 <!-- task content -->
 </div>
 {/each}
 {/if}
</ul>
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Solution 2: Proper Semantic Structure with Button Inside

<augment_code_snippet path="src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte" mode="EDIT">
```svelte
<ul class="border-t border-gray-200 divide-y divide-gray-100" role="list">
 {#if tasks.length === 0}
 <li class="p-4 text-center text-gray-500 text-sm">
 No tasks yet. Add one above!
 </li>
 {:else}
 {#each tasks as task}
 <li>
 <div 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative"
 tabindex="0"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
 >
 <!-- task content -->
 </div>
 </li>
 {/each}
 {/if}
</ul>
```
</augment_code_snippet>

**Solution 1** is cleaner and more common in modern web apps. The `role="listitem"` maintains semantic meaning while allowing the interactive behavior you need.

The key principle: **Interactive elements** need proper roles (`button`, `link`) or `role` attributes, not semantic HTML tags with forced interactivity.

````

**Solution 1** is cleaner and more common in modern web apps. The `role="listitem"` maintains semantic meaning while allowing the interactive behavior you need.

The key principle: **Interactive elements** need proper roles (`button`, `link`) or `role` attributes, not semantic HTML tags with forced interactivity.

role="listitem""}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":1,"type":0,"content":"The issue is that `role="listitem"` doesn't make a `<div>` interactive. You need an interactive role. Here's the fix:

<augment_code_snippet path="src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte" mode="EDIT">
```svelte
<div 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative"
 role="button"
 tabindex="0"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
>
```
</augment_code_snippet>

**Why this works:**
- `role="button"` makes the div interactive (allows `tabindex` and event listeners)
- Maintains keyboard accessibility
- Semantically correct for an element that responds to clicks/keyboard

**Alternative:** If you want to keep list semantics, wrap the interactive div in a proper `<li>`:

<augment_code_snippet path="src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte" mode="EDIT">
```svelte
<ul class="border-t border-gray-200 divide-y divide-gray-100" role="list">
 {#each tasks as task}
 <li>
 <div 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative"
 role="button"
 tabindex="0"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
 >
 <!-- content -->
 </div>
 </li>
 {/each}
</ul>
```
</augment_code_snippet>

The key: **Interactive roles** (`button`, `link`, `menuitem`) allow `tabindex` and event listeners. Semantic roles (`listitem`) don't.

You need an interactive role. Here's the fix:

````svelte path=src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte mode=EDIT
<div 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative"
 role="button"
 tabindex="0"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
>
````

**Why this works:**
- `role="button"` makes the div interactive (allows `tabindex` and event listeners)
- Maintains keyboard accessibility
- Semantically correct for an element that responds to clicks/keyboard

**Alternative:** If you want to keep list semantics, wrap the interactive div in a proper `<li>`:

````svelte path=src/lib/components/TaskList.svelte mode=EDIT
<ul class="border-t border-gray-200 divide-y divide-gray-100" role="list">
 {#each tasks as task}
 <li>
 <div 
 class="flex items-center gap-3 p-4 hover:bg-gray-50 group relative"
 role="button"
 tabindex="0"
 oncontextmenu={(e) => handleTaskRightClick(task.id, e)}
 onkeydown={(e) => handleTaskKeydown(task.id, e)}
 aria-label="Task: {task.title}"
 >
 <!-- content -->
 </div>
 </li>
 {/each}
</ul>
````

The key: **Interactive roles** (`button`, `link`, `menuitem`) allow `tabindex` and event listeners. Semantic roles (`listitem`) don't.

## 19. Avoid Nested Interactive Elements and Use Proper ARIA Roles

HTML doesn't allow nested interactive elements like buttons inside buttons. Use semantic structure with proper ARIA roles instead.

```typescript
// ❌ Nested buttons cause HTML validation errors
<button class="task-row">
 <span>Task title</span>
 <button>Menu</button> // Invalid nesting
</button>

// ✅ Use div with interactive role
<div 
 role="button"
 tabindex="0"
 onkeydown={handleKeydown}
 onclick={handleClick}
 aria-label="Task: Buy groceries"
>
 <span>Task title</span>
 <button>Menu</button> // Valid - button inside div
</div>

// ✅ Or use proper semantic structure
<li>
 <div 
 role="button"
 tabindex="0"
 aria-label="Task: Buy groceries"
 >
 <span>Task title</span>
 <button aria-label="Open menu">⋮</button>
 </div>
</li>
```

**Key Rules:**
- Interactive roles (`button`, `link`, `menuitem`) allow `tabindex` and event listeners
- Semantic roles (`listitem`, `heading`) don't allow interactive behavior
- Use `role="button"` on divs that need click/keyboard interaction
- Always include `aria-label` for screen readers
- Test with keyboard navigation (`Tab`, `Enter`, `Space`)
```

Could you plese tell me how I can capture visual reference of my app and add test for it like in backtestJS."}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":1,"type":0,"content":"I'll help you set up visual regression testing in Playwright, similar to BackstopJS. Playwright has excellent built-in screenshot comparison capabilities.

## Basic Visual Testing Setup

First, add visual comparison configuration to your `playwright.config.ts`:

<augment_code_snippet path="playwright.config.ts" mode="EDIT">
```typescript
export default defineConfig({
	// ... existing config
	
	use: {
		// ... existing use config
		
		// Visual comparison settings
		screenshot: 'only-on-failure',
	},
	
	// Global visual comparison settings
	expect: {
		// Configure screenshot comparison
		toHaveScreenshot: {
			threshold: 0.2,
			maxDiffPixels: 100,
		},
		toMatchSnapshot: {
			threshold: 0.2,
		},
	},
	
	// ... rest of config
});
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Add Visual Tests to Your Todo App

Create visual regression tests in your existing test file:

<augment_code_snippet path="e2e/todo-app.test.ts" mode="EDIT">
```typescript
test.describe('TodoApp - Visual Regression', () => {
 test.beforeEach(async ({ page }) => {
 await page.goto('/todo');
 await page.waitForLoadState('networkidle');
 });

 test('should match initial app layout @visual', async ({ page }) => {
 // Wait for app to be fully loaded
 await expect(page.locator('[data-testid="project-list"]')).toBeVisible();
 
 // Take full page screenshot
 await expect(page).toHaveScreenshot('todo-app-initial.png');
 });

 test('should match app with tasks @visual', async ({ todoPageWithTasks }) => {
 // Ensure both projects are expanded for consistent screenshots
 await todoPageWithTasks.toggleProject('work');
 await todoPageWithTasks.toggleProject('personal');
 await todoPageWithTasks.page.waitForTimeout(500);
 
 await expect(todoPageWithTasks.page).toHaveScreenshot('todo-app-with-tasks.png');
 });

 test('should match context menu appearance @visual', async ({ todoPageWithTasks }) => {
 const taskTitle = testTasks.work.highPriority.title;
 
 await todoPageWithTasks.openTaskContextMenu(taskTitle);
 await expect(todoPageWithTasks.page.locator(selectors.contextMenu)).toBeVisible();
 
 // Screenshot just the context menu area
 await expect(todoPageWithTasks.page.locator(selectors.contextMenu)).toHaveScreenshot('context-menu.png');
 });

 test('should match AI suggestion appearance @visual', async ({ todoPage }) => {
 await todoPage.taskInput.fill('Review quarterly reports');
 
 try {
 await todoPage.waitForAISuggestion();
 await expect(todoPage.aiSuggestion).toHaveScreenshot('ai-suggestion.png');
 } catch {
 console.log('AI suggestion not available - skipping visual test');
 }
 });
});
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Generate Initial Screenshots

Run tests to generate reference screenshots:

```bash
# Generate reference screenshots for the first time
npx playwright test --grep "@visual" --update-snapshots

# Or for specific browser
npx playwright test --grep "@visual" --update-snapshots --project=chromium
```

## Advanced Visual Testing Options

For more control, you can customize screenshot options:

<augment_code_snippet path="e2e/todo-app.test.ts" mode="EDIT">
```typescript
test('should match mobile layout @visual', async ({ page }) => {
 await page.setViewportSize({ width: 375, height: 667 });
 await page.goto('/todo');
 
 await expect(page).toHaveScreenshot('todo-mobile.png', {
 fullPage: true,
 maxDiffPixels: 50,
 });
});

test('should match dark mode @visual', async ({ page }) => {
 // If you have dark mode toggle
 await page.goto('/todo');
 await page.emulateMedia({ colorScheme: 'dark' });
 
 await expect(page).toHaveScreenshot('todo-dark-mode.png');
});
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Update Your Test Scripts

Add visual testing commands to `package.json`:

<augment_code_snippet path="package.json" mode="EDIT">
```json
{
 "scripts": {
 "test:visual": "playwright test --grep '@visual'",
 "test:visual:update": "playwright test --grep '@visual' --update-snapshots",
 "test:visual:ui": "playwright test --grep '@visual' --ui"
 }
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Key Differences from BackstopJS

1. **No separate config file** - everything in `playwright.config.ts`
2. **Built-in comparison** - no external tools needed
3. **Cross-browser by default** - screenshots per browser/device
4. **Integrated with tests** - visual tests alongside functional tests

## Running Visual Tests

```bash
# Run visual tests
npm run test:visual

# Update reference screenshots when UI changes
npm run test:visual:update

# Debug visual differences in UI mode
npm run test:visual:ui
```

The screenshots will be stored in `e2e/todo-app.test.ts-snapshots/` directory and should be committed to version control.

}"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"```"}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":1,"type":0,"content":"## Issue Analysis

The test fails because it's trying to hover over a task that's in a collapsed project. From the page snapshot, the "Work Projects" section shows `▶` (collapsed), but the test is looking for "Fix authentication bug" which is likely in that collapsed section.

The `getTaskByTitle()` method finds the task element even when it's not visible (collapsed), but `hover()` fails because you can't hover over invisible elements.

## Fix

Update the `openTaskContextMenu()` method to ensure the project is expanded first:

<augment_code_snippet path="e2e/pages/TodoPage.ts" mode="EDIT">
```typescript
async openTaskContextMenu(title: string) {
 // Ensure project is expanded before trying to interact with task
 await this.ensureProjectExpanded(title);
 
 const task = await this.getTaskByTitle(title);
 
 // Wait for task to be visible after expansion
 await expect(task).toBeVisible();
 
 // Hover over the task container to reveal the menu button
 await task.hover();
 
 // Wait for the menu button to become visible
 const menuButton = task.locator('button[aria-label*="Open task menu"]');
 await expect(menuButton).toBeVisible();
 
 // Click the menu button
 await menuButton.click();
 
 // Wait for context menu to appear
 await expect(this.page.locator('.dropdown-menu')).toBeVisible();
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Key Changes

1. **Added `ensureProjectExpanded(title)`** - Expands the correct project before interaction
2. **Added visibility check** - `await expect(task).toBeVisible()` ensures the task is actually visible before hovering
3. **Follows Playwright best practices** - Always ensure elements are visible before interaction

This fix ensures the task is in an expanded, visible state before attempting to hover, preventing the timeout error.

The test fails because it's trying to hover over a task that's in a collapsed project. From the page snapshot, the "Work Projects" section shows `▶` (collapsed), but the test is looking for "Fix authentication bug" which is likely in that collapsed section.

The `getTaskByTitle()` method finds the task element even when it's not visible (collapsed), but `hover()` fails because you can't hover over invisible elements.

## Fix

Update the `openTaskContextMenu()` method to ensure the project is expanded first:

````typescript path=e2e/pages/TodoPage.ts mode=EDIT
async openTaskContextMenu(title: string) {
 // Ensure project is expanded before trying to interact with task
 await this.ensureProjectExpanded(title);
 
 const task = await this.getTaskByTitle(title);
 
 // Wait for task to be visible after expansion
 await expect(task).toBeVisible();
 
 // Hover over the task container to reveal the menu button
 await task.hover();
 
 // Wait for the menu button to become visible
 const menuButton = task.locator('button[aria-label*="Open task menu"]');
 await expect(menuButton).toBeVisible();
 
 // Click the menu button
 await menuButton.click();
 
 // Wait for context menu to appear
 await expect(this.page.locator('.dropdown-menu')).toBeVisible();
}
````

## Key Changes

1. **Added `ensureProjectExpanded(title)`** - Expands the correct project before interaction
2. **Added visibility check** - `await expect(task).toBeVisible()` ensures the task is actually visible before hovering
3. **Follows Playwright best practices** - Always ensure elements are visible before interaction

This fix ensures the task is in an expanded, visible state before attempting to hover, preventing the timeout error.

Your photo editor changes might be within this tolerance.

Here's how to test visual regression properly:

## 1. Temporarily Lower the Threshold

<augment_code_snippet path="e2e/todo-app.test.ts" mode="EDIT">
```typescript
test('should match mobile layout @visual', async ({ page }) => {
 await page.setViewportSize({ width: 375, height: 667 });
 await page.goto('/todo');
 
 await expect(page).toHaveScreenshot('todo-mobile.png', {
 fullPage: true,
 maxDiffPixels: 0, // Set to 0 to catch any difference
 threshold: 0.1, // Lower threshold for stricter comparison
 });
});
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## 2. Make a More Obvious Change

Instead of subtle photo editing, make a bigger change to the reference image:
- Add a large colored rectangle
- Change a significant portion of the image
- Or delete part of the image

## 3. Test the Failure Flow

```bash
# Run the specific test to see it fail
npx playwright test --grep "should match mobile layout" --project=chromium

# Check the HTML report to see visual diff
npx playwright show-report
```

## 4. Better Test Configuration

For reliable visual testing, configure global thresholds:

<augment_code_snippet path="playwright.config.ts" mode="EDIT">
```typescript
export default defineConfig({
 // ... existing config
 
 expect: {
 timeout: 3000,
 toHaveScreenshot: {
 threshold: 0.2, // Default threshold
 maxDiffPixels: 10, // Lower default tolerance
 animations: 'disabled', // Disable animations for consistency
 },
 },
 
 // ... rest of config
});
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## 5. Verify Your Test Setup

<augment_code_snippet path="e2e/todo-app.test.ts" mode="EDIT">
```typescript
test('should match mobile layout @visual', async ({ page }) => {
 await page.setViewportSize({ width: 375, height: 667 });
 await page.goto('/todo');
 
 // Wait for content to load
 await page.waitForLoadState('networkidle');
 await expect(page.locator('[data-testid="project-list"]')).toBeVisible();
 
 await expect(page).toHaveScreenshot('todo-mobile.png', {
 fullPage: true,
 maxDiffPixels: 5, // Very strict
 });
});
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Debug Steps

1. **Check the actual file location**: Look for `e2e/todo-app.test.ts-snapshots/todo-mobile-chromium-darwin.png`
2. **Make a dramatic change**: Paint half the image red
3. **Run with strict settings**: `maxDiffPixels: 0`
4. **Check HTML report**: Visual diff will show exactly what changed

The test should definitely fail with obvious changes and strict thresholds!

You're running the test with different **projects** than the screenshot files you're editing.

Looking at your files:
- You have `todo-mobile-**mobile-chrome**-darwin.png` 
- But also `todo-mobile-**chromium**-darwin.png`, `todo-mobile-**firefox**-darwin.png`, etc.

The test is probably running on a different browser project than the file you're editing.

## Check Which Project is Running

<augment_code_snippet path="e2e/todo-app.test.ts" mode="EDIT">
```typescript
test('should match mobile layout @visual', async ({ page }, testInfo) => {
 console.log(`Running on project: ${testInfo.project.name}`);
 
 await page.setViewportSize({ width: 375, height: 667 });
 await page.goto('/todo');
 
 await expect(page).toHaveScreenshot('todo-mobile.png', {
 fullPage: true,
 maxDiffPixels: 0, // Set to 0 to force failure
 });
});
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Run Specific Project

```bash
# Run only on chromium project
npx playwright test --grep "should match mobile layout" --project=chromium

# Run only on mobile-chrome project 
npx playwright test --grep "should match mobile layout" --project=mobile-chrome
```

## Check Your Playwright Config Projects

Your `playwright.config.ts` has these projects:

<augment_code_snippet path="playwright.config.ts" mode="EXCERPT">
```typescript
projects: [
 {
 name: 'chromium',
 use: { ...devices['Desktop Chrome'] },
 },
 {
 name: 'firefox', 
 use: { ...devices['Desktop Firefox'] },
 },
 {
 name: 'webkit',
 use: { ...devices['Desktop Safari'] },
 },
 {
 name: 'mobile-chrome',
 use: { ...devices['Pixel 5'] },
 },
],
```
</augment_code_snippet>

## Force the Test to Use Specific Project

Edit the file that matches the project you're running:

1. **If running `chromium`**: Edit `todo-mobile-chromium-darwin.png`
2. **If running `mobile-chrome`**: Edit `todo-mobile-mobile-chrome-darwin.png`
3. **If running `firefox`**: Edit `todo-mobile-firefox-darwin.png`

## Or Run All Projects to See Which Fails

```bash
# This will run on ALL projects and show which one fails
npx playwright test --grep "should match mobile layout"
```

The key is matching the **project name** in the filename with the project you're actually running!
